epp:phrase.p: The Construction Management Abstracts site is a database of titles, authors, abstracts, and keywords. We bring together material from a wide range of sources: leading journals in construction management, recent ARCOM Conference Proceedings, and PhD theses.

Academic study in this field can be challenging to navigate. Construction is typically a technical or scientific subject, while management draws on social sciences such as organisation studies, economics, and law. Construction management sits at the intersection of these traditions, creating new opportunities for using social science to understand and reflect on the construction sector. While new insights are developed for both social sciences and construction science, this combination can also make it harder to locate relevant literature — especially for those new to the field or working across disciplinary boundaries.

This catalogue is one of ARCOM’s key contributions to the field. It is intended to support access to previous research for both researchers and practitioners. By making abstracts and related information easy to find, we hope to encourage greater use of existing work, and to help reduce duplication of effort. By providing this catalogue, we hope to facilitate access to previous research for researchers and practitioners in this area.
As well as papers from the ARCOM Conference Proceedings since 1997, the database includes complete metadata — titles, authors, abstracts, and keywords — from the following journals:

epp:phrase.p: Finally, we are also collating PhD theses from around the world that help form the underpinning to new developments and insights. (If your abstract is not yet included, we would be glad to hear from you.) The database is updated regularly with new papers from the selected journals, as well as each new set of ARCOM Conference Proceedings. Earlier ARCOM papers (those published before 1997) are not available online. If you are looking for one of these, your university or institutional library may be able to help via Inter-Library Loan. If you are unsure how to request this, your librarian should be able to guide you.

This service originally took the form of printed volumes, available for purchase. Income from those sales helped cover the initial cost of setting up the online system. Now that these costs have been met, ongoing maintenance is supported through ARCOM’s core budget. We no longer provide hard copies. As a learned society, we see it as our responsibility to make this resource freely available to the widest possible audience. If your library still holds printed editions, please consider letting them know about this online version.

If you are the publisher or editor of a journal that you believe should be included in this database, we would be glad to consider your suggestion. To help us assess it fairly, we ask that you provide a brief analysis showing how often articles from your journal cite (and are cited by) publications already in the database. We can offer guidance on how to compile this information using tools such as Scopus. Once your analysis is ready, please send it to the email address below. We will review any request in the context of the broader citation landscape and consider its relevance to the field.

ul.li: Entering the same term in more than one field restricts the search to results present in ALL those fields, like AND. At the bottom of the fields list, there is an option to change this to search for any condition rather than all conditions (Retrieved records must fulfill:). You can also change the sequence in which the results are presented (the default is chonological)

Within most of the search fields, there is a drop-down menu. The default is "all of". Its effect is:
All of these words: matches only if all appear (like AND)
Any of these words: matches if any appear (like OR)
Quotation marks are ignored. For example, searching for "urban development" is the same as searching for urban development, i.e., two separate words.
Common short words, called "stop words" (e.g., and, or, the), are ignored and cannot be used as Boolean operators.

Stemming means using the root of a word to match all variants. This is applied automatically in every search. For example:
advanced will also match advance, advancing, etc.
buildings matches building, build, etc.
After your first search, you can use "Refine Search" to narrow results further by adding more AND filters or expanding them as needed.

div.p: There is also an option to undertake a Simple Search, at the top right of any screen in this site. This automatically searches all indexed fields such as authors, titles, and journal names. The same basic rules apply to both search types regarding punctuation, stop words, and stemming.

p.small: N.B. Descriptive scope is a count how many of the five facets of empirical research are indicated by the words used in title, abstract and keywords. It is not intended as a judgement on the research; merely a count of the kind of word we would expect to indicate Phenomenon, Concepts, Theoretical framing, Empirical techniques, Analytical techniques. If all five are present, then 5 PCTEA will indicate this.
